title: Mudwater Gospel
description: Category 4. Direct hit. Mandatory evacuation. But you're standing in your grandmother's church, and sixty-three years of gospel music are staring back at you from the walls.

scenes.title: The Warning
scenes.content:
Radio says Category 4. Direct hit. Twelve hours.

You're in the church your grandmother built with her own hands after the last flood. Pews she sanded. Windows she picked out from a catalog. Hymnals with her handwriting in the margins.

Phone buzzes. Your brother: Roads close in 2 hours. You coming or not?

Through the window, Old Mae's still on her porch across the street. Ninety-one years old. Hasn't evacuated since 1965.

choices.text: Load what you can, go now
Stay. This church has survived worse.

scenes.title: Mae's Porch
scenes.content:
"I ain't leaving, sugar."

She rocks steady, watching the sky turn green. Hurricane sky. Bad sky.

"Buried three husbands from this porch. Raised seven children. The Lord knows where to find me."

She pats the chair beside her.

"Got a generator. Got canned peaches. Got stories about your grandmother you never heard." She almost smiles. "That woman had some fire in her before she got respectable."

scenes.title: Loading Up
scenes.content:
Work fast. Think later.

Photo of the original congregation, 1961. Grandmother's handwritten hymnbook. The stained glass is too heavy. You take a picture instead.

Deacon Williams pulls up. "Need help?"

Behind him, the sky's getting darker.

scenes.title: The Pews
scenes.content:
Four of you. Every rope in the truck. The pews weigh more than sin, your grandmother used to say.

First raindrops hit as you load the last one. Big drops. Warm.

"That's it," Williams says. "We gotta move."

The church looks empty now. Wrong. Like a body without a soul.

You get in your car. Don't look back.

scenes.title: The Font
scenes.content:
Baptismal font has names carved inside. Every soul baptized since 1927. Your grandmother. Your mother. You.

Takes both of you to lift it into the truck bed.

"This thing's seen more floods than any of us," Williams says.

The rain starts before you reach the highway.

scenes.title: Mae's Stories
scenes.content:
Storm screams for eight hours. Mae's house shudders but holds.

Between gusts, she talks. Your grandmother sneaking out to blues clubs. Secret romance with a traveling preacher before your grandfather. The time she faced down the Klan with nothing but a hymnal and a cast-iron skillet.

"Fire in her," Mae says. "Pure fire."

Dawn comes. Street's a river. But Mae's porch sits just above the water line.

And across the way, the steeple's still pointing at the sky.

scenes.title: Convincing Mae
scenes.content:
"My truck can handle the water. We go now, we make it."

Mae stops rocking. Looks at you hard.

"You got your grandmother's stubbornness." She sighs. "Fine. But I'm bringing my records. Mahalia Jackson gets water damage, I'm blaming you personally."

You help her to the car. She's lighter than you expected. Fragile in a way she never seemed before.

"Buildings can be rebuilt," she says as you pull away. "It's the people that matter. Your grandmother knew that. Why she built a church instead of a monument."

In the rearview, the Delta disappears behind sheets of rain.

scenes.title: The Shelter
scenes.content:
High school gymnasium. Cots. Red Cross blankets. Crying kids and worried faces.

Mae finds a corner, starts unpacking her records like she's setting up for a party.

Your phone's almost dead. One text from your brother: Thank God. Thought we lost you.

Outside, the wind howls. Inside, Mae starts humming. Low at first. Then louder.

Someone joins in. Then someone else. By the time the eye passes over, the whole gym is singing "How Great Thou Art."

Your grandmother would have loved this.

scenes.title: After
scenes.content:
Three weeks later. Water's down. You drive back.

The church is gone. Roof caved in. Walls buckled. Pews you didn't take are matchsticks in the mud.

But down the road, the community center's standing. The pews you saved are inside. They're holding Sunday service there now. Same hymns. Same spirit.

Mae's on her porch again. House needs work, but she's there.

"See?" she calls out. "Told you the Lord knows where to find us."

The building was never the church. You get that now.

The people are.

scenes.title: The Hidden Room
scenes.content:
You're checking the walls one last time when you feel it. A draft. Cold air from solid stone.

Behind the altar, a panel. Warped with age, but it opens.

Inside: newspapers from 1964. Photographs of meetings. Names you recognize from history books. Letters in your grandmother's handwriting.

This wasn't just a church.

choices.text: Leave it. Some secrets should stay buried.

scenes.title: The Documents
scenes.content:
Your grandmother wasn't just building a church. She was running a station on the underground.

Safe houses. Escape routes. Names of families she helped move north. Maps with paths marked in red ink.

One letter mentions a "final cache" hidden where "only family would look."

The storm's getting closer. You have minutes. But this could change how people remember her. How they remember this whole community.

scenes.title: The Truth
scenes.content:
You dig behind the cemetery in the last hour before the storm hits. Right where the letter said. Under a headstone that's been there since 1963.

Steel box. Waterproof. Inside: recordings. Dozens of them. People telling their stories, naming names, documenting what really happened.

Your grandmother didn't just save lives. She made sure no one could deny what happened here.

You barely make it to your car. Six months later, historians call it the most important civil rights discovery in decades.

Your grandmother's secrets become foundation stones for something new.

scenes.title: Riding It Out
scenes.content:
Bad idea. You knew it was a bad idea.

Water under the door. Ankles. Knees. You climb to the choir loft.

The church groans. Wind screams. Everything shakes.

You start singing. Old songs. Her songs. The ones she taught you before you could read.

And somehow, impossibly, you hear voices. Mae from across the street. The Williams family. Others you can't see. All singing.

The building might not make it. But the church is wherever the singing is.

scenes.title: The Rally
scenes.content:
You don't leave. You climb the church steps and ring the bell. Three times. Emergency signal, from the old days.

They come. Deacon Williams with his bad hip. The Johnson family. Teenagers who usually skip service. Old folks who remember your grandmother's first sermon.

Thirty-two people in a church about to face the worst storm in a decade.

You don't have a sermon prepared. Just stand where she stood.

"She always said this building was just wood and nails." Your voice carries. "Said the real church was us."

Mae starts humming. The sound builds. Voices join in.

The lights go out. The singing doesn't stop.

choices.text: Lead them to the shelter together
Stay and sing until the storm passes

scenes.title: Together
scenes.content:
"Everybody who can walk, help somebody who can't. Williams, you take point. I've got the rear."

You file out into the wind. Thirty-two people holding hands in a chain, moving through ankle-deep water toward the school.

Mae's between you and the Johnson boy. She's humming the whole way.

"This is the church!" someone shouts over the wind. "Right here! This is it!"

They're right. Walls didn't make it holy. The people do.

The building doesn't make it through the night. But everyone does.

In the morning, you start planning how to rebuild. Not the building. Something better.
